title: Bellator Europe 5's Yannick Bahati has no fear of Melvin Manhoef in Milan headliner
text:
Mixed martial artists are a different breed. Their commitment to training in grueling, close-quarters competition makes them comfortable in the uncomfortable.

But, as a youngster, Bellator light heavyweight contender Yannick Bahati had to get comfortable with one the most uncomfortable situations anyone could ever find themselves in.

“I was born in the Congo, the DRC,” he told MMA Junkie ahead of his main event appearance at Bellator Europe 5 on Oct. 12. “In the Congo, there was a lot of war. I’ve been involved in three wars as a youngster and have seen young men die in front of my own eyes.”

Thankfully for Bahati (9-4 MMA, 1-0 BMMA), his family was eventually able to get themselves out of the country and away from danger and, with young Bahati still only 10 years ld, they moved to the United Kingdom in search of a fresh, safe start.

“Living in the Congo isn’t the best, or the safest, environment for a young kid,” he continued. “So my parents decided they wanted a better life for us and we eventually moved to the U.K.”

Bahati, who at the time could speak Swahili and French, but not English, found himself involved in fights both in school and on the street as he struggled to come to terms with day-to-day life in his new country. But eventually, he found his feet, by working his hands.

“In my early teens – 15, 16 years old – I started doing boxing and competing as an amateur in the ABAs (Britain’s amateur boxing championships) and the nationals,” he explained. “Eventually, when I was 19, I moved to Birmingham for university, and while I was there I started learning mixed martial arts with the same team as Leon Edwards. We started almost at the same time and we’ve been training together from the start.”

Alongside Edwards and his brother, Bellator middleweight contender Fabian, UFC middleweight Tom Breese, former UFC athletes Vaughan Lee and Paul Taylor, plus Cage Warriors middleweight title challenger Nathias Frederick and EFC flyweight champion Jake Hadley, Bahati is part of a formidable lineup of talent that trained closely together at Birmingham gym UTC. But when the gym closed its doors for the final time a couple of years ago, Bahati and his teammates collectively took the decision to stick together and make their new home at their grappling gym at Team Renegade.

“With our gym closing down, we all relocated to Team Renegade,” he explained. “We used to go there for our grappling, but with UTC closing down we all moved there and we’ve made it more into an MMA gym. The guys are in all the top shows in the world: UFC, Bellator, Cage Warriors, EFC. We’ve got top-quality lads, and that’s the great thing about our gym. We’re all surrounded by great athletes, young guys that are all after the same dream.”

Bahati captured the middleweight titles in South African promotion EFC, then British promotion BAMMA before moving up to light heavyweight and signing for Bellator. Now, after picking up a first-round submission finish on his promotional debut, he’s been handed a main event slot in Italy against an MMA legend – Dutch knockout artist Melvin Manhoef.

“Fighting a legend like Melvin Manhoef is a dream come true,” he said. “Being signed to Bellator exclusively, I had a hit list of who I wanted to fight in the future. I had Alessio Sakara, I had Karl Moore and I also had Melvin Manhoef. For me to get him first, I definitely didn’t expect that. But I’ve just hit the jackpot, so why not?!”

While Bahati is excited to face such a big name in his next fight, he revealed his friends and family weren’t quite so happy for him after learning the identity of his upcoming opponent.

“When I got offered the fight I was over the moon. I’m fighting Melvin Manhoef, you know? That’s a great name to have on your record,” he said. “But then when I told my family and my friends: ’I’ve got a big fight’, they said: ‘Who are you fighting?’ And when I said: ‘Melvin Manhoef’, the look on their faces was hilarious. They were literally petrified for me!”

But after everything he experienced so early in his life, very little scares 29-year-old Bahati these days, and he said he is fully prepared to step into the cage and take on the fearsome puncher from the Netherlands. “The Black Mamba” believes his own striking can cause problems for Manhoef (31-14-1 MMA, 3-3 BMMA), but said his grappling may well prove to be the deciding factor on fight night in Milan.

“I’m up to the challenge. A fight is a fight and Melvin is human, with two arms, two legs, so it ain’t no big deal,” he said. “Everybody knows what he brings to the table, I believe he’s got 30 wins, 28 KOs, that’s a 93% knockout ratio. But I don’t believe he’s ever submitted anyone in the past, so that’s something to look at.

“I believe his wrestling defense is very good, and he’s a (BJJ) brown belt, but I believe if the fight hits the floor, I’ll treat him like a white belt – that’s just the honest truth. Me on top, I’m a handful for anybody. He’s a striker, but he isn’t the most technical striker in the world. I believe my striking is better than his. He’s been chinned and I’ve seen him hit the canvas many, many times.

“I can expose him everywhere. I can expose him on the feet and I can expose him on the floor. Plus, his gas tank ain’t the best. He’s only got one round in him. But, at the end of the day, Melvin’s Melvin, and what he brings is dangerous, dangerous knockout power.”
description: Yannick Bahati says he is ready to face, and defeat, fearsome striker Melvin Manhoef in the main event of Bellator Europe 5.
